title: Flaming is punished harder than it should be.
body:
Hello, as someone who has been banned before for flaming, I will say that the system is too harsh on the player, eventually resulting in suspensions/perma bans. And for someone who, like me, is very quick to snap at a teammate for even saying anything remotely snide or rude in any way and be completely thrown off of my game (It's not easy for me to just want to turn off chat because in order for that to work I would have to mute pings and other things as well, which would make it hard to communicate crucial information. I also have a very bad temper and am quick to snap at somebody and it isn't as easy to manage as you would think.) While I am not saying that flaming and toxic behavior is an unpunishable offense, I do believe that the measures it can be taken to at some point are extreme, especially when someone may put a lot of money into an account that at some point ends up permabanned.

I believe that, a better solution than resorting to suspensions and bans, are chat suspensions, and chat bans. Somewhat similar to what we have now with the chat restrictions, I believe that instead of completely banning them from the game, it would be better to just cut off their chat interactions all together either temporarily, or permanently (like with suspensions and permabans). They would simply completely disable the chat for the player (either limiting them to only seeing chat, or not seeing it at all and only seeing/using pings) and make honor unattainable.

To me, a player being banned for saying negative things in chat (possibly with the exception of slurs and hate speech) and general flaming, isn't enough to warrant a ban from the game outright, but it is enough to warrant chat limitations like mentioned above. If a player who has been repeatedly reported for being negative in chat and has been flaming their teammates consistently, they should at some point get hit by a chat suspension, followed by a chat ban if they continue to be verbally toxic. The chat suspension/ban would not allow messages to be sent whatsoever and would limit you to pings only, as well as resetting/disabling your honor. It could also be made to forcefully disable the chat outright, but that decision could be left to a player if the chat tilts them that much without being able to respond (like it would me.)

I would like to know if it would even be possible for something like this to happen? Because in my opinion, the only people who should be banned outright are the people who are consistently inting in games, trolling/griefing, and other things of the sort (of course hacking/cheating as well).

Edit: This might get deleted from downvotes and so I just wanna say that you guys seem to be just rejecting this idea without a second thought.

replies.body:
There already are chat restriction punishments.
Nobody else should suffer toxic people  simply because you cant control your actions. That's your problem, not League's nor Riots.
I'm saying that they should just disable the chat for a repeat offense player entirely. Not just restrictions.

This led to players griefing in ways much harder to detect and punish when they did it for a restriction.

Riot will furthermore not punish a players' teammates for their inability to behave. And really, that's what disabling chat does. There are many things you can't really say with pings - and even the things you can say are almost always less confusing and easier overall to say in chat.

Like if you're a jungler and want to explain your pathing to your teammate so they understand when to expect you: "blue gromp then top" - they know you're coming but can monitor when on their minimap.

Or if you're an ADC and you want to explain the synergy you want to use with your teammate - maybe you're xayan and rakan and you wanna be on the same page about whether you root first or rakan goes in first. Can't do that with pings at all.

Point being, disabling chat inconveniences their team.

I almost never see people explaining these types of things in chat. Like, it's such a rare occurrence that I believe that wouldn't really be something to worry about, and would be an overall better change. As well as, the likelihood of someone being chat banned, but also doing that sort of thing without just being with a duo queue partner, seems very unlikely.

So.. because you yourself (and your teammates) can't communicate well using chat to assist in planning/etc... it should mean others should have to be subjected to that too?

For the record, I see this sort of behavior in **virtually all** of my games.

Well not everyone is gonna have the same experience with what they do/don't see in their games. But also, I have friends who have mentioned to me that they rarely see people use chat besides to flame their teammates/enemies.

But I don't see how this type of change would affect players who are not chat banned. Because the player who is chat banned could have the choice to disable chat altogether, or still SEE chat, and not be able to interact with it in any way. I'm not saying it would outright delete the chat from said player altogether, it would be up to them to completely disable it or not, and so I apologize if that's how I made it sound. But the chat banned player would not be able to talk for themselves, instead of just being limited to a certain number of messages
It would prevent that player from being able to communicate in chat something they want to. In fact, that’s the exact reason chat restrictions are a thing, not chat suspensions.

Well it would be better than to just completely remove them from the game entirely and potentially losing a customer, would it not? Because I know that while, yes, I would be frustrated I couldn't talk, I would also realize that I did it to myself and that is my punishment. While, a ban would be more infuriating to me than just not being able to talk. At that point, it would be "At least I can still play the game with all of the skins I have accrued over time" rather than "Wow, I just lost hundreds of dollars because somebody tilted me."

At least, that's coming from someone who enjoys skins and such. Say what you will about that, but that is not the point of this post.

Even if they couldn't communicate, they still brought it onto themselves, and at least they can still play the game and not have to start all over.

Riot has said they don’t want the money from toxic players. It’s a novel idea I guess.

The point isn’t to make it easier for toxic players to keep playing. It’s that they stop playing.
That's not true, otherwise they would make it to where it would be an IP ban so they couldn't make more accounts as easily.

IP bans are useless considering how easy it is to circumvent it, and possibly harmful for grouped connections such as cybercafes.
There is no real way to prevent someone to remake an account on this game.

On another note, if you have trouble with chat, you can disable it by yourself in the options. It's a recent, welcomed addition for players who can't control themselves and search for a solution.
_**Edit:** didn't see you already answered to that part to someone else. Well, it's a matter of maturity and responsibility. If you need to be stopped because you can't yourself, you can't discuss the way they do it. There are softer ways than the path you're walking, but you decided it wasn't enough for you._

Well, for someone who is like me (And I just recently took the tilt type test, got Paladin) it is extremely difficult to want to turn off chat, or keep it off if something is going wrong. I act immediately to try and either put someone in their place, or try to force plays myself because I lose faith in my teammates when they start playing badly. And when they flame me, I immediately snap back by telling them that it's their fault for feeding that I am now in the bad spot I am in.

No they wouldn't, because IP bans don't work.
To give just one example of why IP bans are a bad idea: If you IP ban me, I might not even notice because I'll have a different IP within 24 hours.

If a punishment is so easy to circumvent that you can do so by accident, it's not a good punishment.

Flaming is punished in 4 steps unless someone used Zero Tolerance.
10 game CR
25 game CR
14 day ban
Perm

Gameplay gets 2 steps.
14 day ban
Perm

You say you can't turn off chat yourself, but Riot should force people to. Don't you think these other people are like you and want to communicate but snap easily? They already have given us the ability to opt out of Ally chat, why isn't that enough?

And to answer as to why it isn't enough, some people don't want to sit there and let others just put them down, and/or have a need to explain themselves or defend themselves, which can spiral out of control because people tend to just tell you "trash player, uninstall" among other things without even considering it might just be a bad game or something.

Because you can easily go back in and turn it on and flame someone who is excessive pinging you or who is feeding and whatnot. Without access to be able to send a message whatsoever, the only thing you can do is ping back, or int. And I'm not someone who goes in and ints when someone gets on my nerves, but I can't speak for the types of people who are.

There was a period of time where poor chat behavior would only give the player more stacks of chat restriction.

During that time Riot found that players with an extremely high amount of chat restrictions often found other means to vent their anger at their teammates when they couldn't do it through chat. And griefing behavior is a lot harder to catch and hold someone accountable for because it often looks ambiguous when compared to unintentional mistakes.

So that type of punishment system was scrapped. The conclusion was that if someone was incapable of controlling themselves in chat despite knowing it could get them in trouble and being punished for it several times already, it's unlikely that only blocking one outlet such as chat would get them to behave.

It would certainly solve the problem for people who are only verbal and never start inting because of the fact that someone pissed them off. Which, I'm sure is most people. The people who int when they're mad at someone is a different story because that just comes down to repeat offenses (and if riot would actually take time to improve their reporting system like having people review vods, they could have people hired/volunteer to make their own judgement on a vod, and see if it could be classified as actual inting, or an off game. Perhaps level 5 honor players if volunteers)

> It would certainly solve the problem for people who are only verbal and never start inting because of the fact that someone pissed them off. Which, I'm sure is most people.

What you personally may do should you no longer be able to chat I can't say for certain. But previous precedent showed that endless chat restrictions caused more problems as a whole.

>The people who int when they're mad at someone is a different story because that just comes down to repeat offenses (and if riot would actually take time to improve their reporting system like having people review vods, they could have people hired/volunteer to make their own judgement on a vod, and see if it could be classified as actual inting, or an off game. Perhaps level 5 honor players if volunteers)

Not enough personnel to review matches, especially considering the amount of time it takes to watch a match. Having honor level 5 does not mean you're a reliable judge of if someone was intentionally feeding or not.

Keep in mind there are millions of players. Out of those millions of games there are lots of players that are quick to assume someone is intentionally feeding. It's not like intentional feeding reports are only coming from those that are making well reasoned judgement without bias.

Even if only 1% of 1 million matches have a intentional feeding report that would mean 10000 games to review. And it's not like reports just stop while Riot takes several days to get through a single day worth of reports.

The behavioral system **needs** to be highly automated for such a large and tense game.

But out of those millions of players, I'm sure there are more than enough people who would be perfectly willing to volunteer or even be hired if Riot wanted to hire them on, that are reliable people to judge what is and what isn't inting/trolling. Of course they would have to be made sure that they are not gonna just look at a few numbers and go "yep, defo troll" and just lay down the ban button.

But I know something like that won't happen because that requires too many resources for them to want to do something like that, even if it would make for an overall better player experience. They want to spend the least amount of money possible.

This doesn't solve the personnel problem. The amount of people who would realistically apply, be reliable, and not disappear the instant something else came up at the same time is infinitely small.

>Of course they would have to be made sure that they are not gonna just look at a few numbers and go "yep, defo troll" and just lay down the ban button.

That sounds like even more personnel necessary.

> But I know something like that won't happen because that requires too many resources for them to want to do something like that, even if it would make for an overall better player experience. They want to spend the least amount of money possible.

Previously, there was a Tribunal that allowed players to judge cases. Even that fell extremely short of keeping up with the reporting coming in. And that one wasn't picky at choosing which people to allow to vote nor did they require people to watch videos. So that was shelved as well.

The Tribunal barely offered any incentive for players to consider it.

And a lot of people also want the Tribunal to come back.

> [{quoted}](name=OrangeZoda,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=2sMTEQhZ,comment-id=000000000000000000010000,timestamp=2019-10-22T09:34:49.350+0000)
>
> The Tribunal barely offered any incentive for players to consider it.

Increasing the rewards to take part in the Tribunal also increases the chance that people use the Tribunal for the reward rather than a desire to judge cases accurately.

Despite the low rewards of the old Tribunal it still had some people who opted for speed rather than accuracy to get the rewards quickly. Increasing the rewards would only increase this group of people.

> And a lot of people also want the Tribunal to come back.

If more people kept up with the Tribunal while also staying accurate then it wouldn't have gone away. But that didn't happen.

If it's not good enough for the task then it's not good enough for the task.

The issue is that there won’t be unless Riot incurs a great cost. Further, any form of rewards would encourage fake voting just to try to get them.

Consider this also - let’s say Riot offers 100 RP per month if you log in and review one case per week. That still requires tons and tons of people, plus, some of them will use the RP from this in lieu of buying RP themselves - thus cutting into their revenue.

I highly doubt Riot would be losing as much money as you think they would be, by actually making the report system something that actually works better than just discouraging people to stand up for themselves when they're being harassed/flamed in a game.

Did you find something in Riot's store [allowing you to break the ToS](https://i.imgur.com/AvDSnZF.png)? No, because such a service is not offered. Regardless of how much money you spend, you are required to follow the same rules as everyone else. If the IFS determines that you've been validly reported in violation of those rules, you'll be punished according to those rules. If you wanted to avoid a punishment, you should've followed the rules.

Riot's punishment system used to hand out stacking chat restrictions, such that consistently toxic players basically had a permanent chat restriction. Unfortunately, it turns out that such players used their few chat opportunities to be toxic, and, when they couldn't be as toxic as they wanted to, they resorted to committing non-chat offenses such as griefing (following someone around and taking their farm, using wall abilities to interfere with their play, etc.) or inting. The purpose of the punishment system is to eliminate rule-breaking, not make it worse. Thus, if a couple chat restrictions don't make any difference in a player's misbehavior, the system ramps up the punishments until the player is permabanned and thus unable to use that account to break any more rules ever again.

Your opinion of the rules is of zero relevance. When a cop stops you for going 40 in a 25 zone, you can claim "I think the limit should be 45 here" all you want. You're still getting a ticket. If a librarian asks you to keep your voice down while you use the facilities, shouting that libraries should be loud will simply get you escorted out. If you go to a friend's house who insists that you remove your shoes while you're in their home, "that's a stupid rule and I do what I want" will lose you a friend. If you are using someone else's services, facilities, equipment, etc., you abide by their rules or you deal with the consequences. If you think the rules should change, that is a completely different conversation (and I wouldn't give a plugged nickel for your chances at convincing Riot to change their rules to allow behavior like yours).

From [Riot's support knowledgebase](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/360024051193-Understanding-Different-Ban-Types-FAQs):

> We work with the overall community and within our own company guidelines to identify what disruptive behavior is and what the consequences for those behaviors should be. We understand that it can be difficult to know where the line is, which is why we provide chat logs and we have a few tiers in the ban process in order to allow for you to learn and grow.

That doesn't change that a ban shouldn't be necessary for toxic behavior. A chat ban would be just as effective. And people who resort to trolling/griefing? Hell, they were gonna do it anyways, so there's no preventing that.

Yes much too harsh, most games ignore the fact that it exists and it usually is much less toxic than league. Because league has "declared war" on toxicity it has blown it out of proportion and now it is a real issue because when someone is told not to do something they want to do it more.
